This question requires some basic knowledge about seismometers and their function. A seismometer is a device used to measure and detect earthquakes and seismic waves. Seismic waves are produced by the movement of the Earth's tectonic plates and are not present on stars. Therefore, a seismometer would be ineffective on a star. 

Options (A), (C), and (D) are incorrect because seismometers are commonly used on dry land, on the coast, and on continents to monitor and measure earthquakes.

This question requires an understanding of what a seismometer is and how it works. A seismometer is an instrument used to measure and record seismic activity, such as earthquakes. Seismic activity is caused by the movement of tectonic plates beneath the Earth's surface. Therefore, a seismometer would be ineffective on a star (option B) because stars do not have tectonic plate movement or earthquakes. Options A, C, and D are incorrect because a seismometer can be effective on dry land, on the coast, and on a continent since all of these areas can experience seismic activity.

A seismometer is used to detect and measure earthquakes and seismic waves. It relies on the vibrations and movements of the earth's crust to function properly. Option (B) is the correct answer because a star does not have an earth's crust or seismic activity, so a seismometer would have no purpose on a star. Option (A) is incorrect because seismometers are commonly used on dry land to monitor seismic activity. Option (C) is also incorrect because seismometers are often placed on the coast to monitor earthquakes and tsunamis.
